Q: For Halloween Debby and her sister combined the candy they received. Debby had 32 pieces of candy while her sister had 42. If they ate 35 pieces the first night, how many pieces do they have left?
R:
Debby and her sister had a total of 32 + 42 = 74 pieces of candy.
After eating 35 pieces, they have 74 - 35 = 39 pieces of candy left.

Q: A pet store had 13 siamese cats and 5 house cats. During a sale they sold 10 cats. How many cats do they have left?
R: The pet store originally had 18 cats (13 siamese + 5 house). After selling 10 cats, they have 8 cats left.

Q: Luke was trying to expand his game collection. He bought 2 games from a friend and bought 2 more at a garage sale. If 2 of the games didn't work, how many good games did he end up with?
R: Luke ended up with 2 good games.

Q: The school cafeteria ordered 42 red apples and 7 green apples for students lunches. But, if only 9 students wanted fruit, how many extra did the cafeteria end up with?
R:
The cafeteria ordered a total of 49 apples (42 red + 7 green). If only 9 students wanted fruit, they would need a maximum of 9 apples. 

Therefore, the cafeteria ended up with 40 extra apples (49 total - 9 needed).

Q: Lana picked 36 tulips and 37 roses to make flower bouquets. If she only used 70 of the flowers though, how many extra flowers did Lana pick?
R:
Lana picked a total of 36 + 37 = 73 flowers.
She had 73 - 70 = 3 extra flowers.

Q: Carol and her mom were picking carrots from their garden. Carol picked 29 and her mother picked 16. If only 38 of the carrots were good, how many bad carrots did they have?
R:
They picked a total of 29 + 16 = 45 carrots.
If only 38 of them were good, then they had 45 - 38 = 7 bad carrots.

Q: Roger had 16 dollars. For his birthday he got 28 more dollars but spent 25 on a new game. How much money does he have now?
R:
Roger now has 19 dollars. 

To find out, you can add the 28 dollars he received for his birthday to his original 16 dollars: 

16 + 28 = 44 

Then, you can subtract the 25 dollars he spent on the new game: 

44 - 25 = 19

Q: While on vacation, Megan took 15 pictures at the zoo and 18 at the museum. If she later deleted 31 of the pictures, how many pictures from her vacation did she still have?
R:
Megan had a total of 15 + 18 = <<15+18=33>>33 pictures.
After deleting 31 pictures, she had 33 - 31 = <<33-31=2>>2 pictures left. Answer: \boxed{2}.

Q: Rachel bought two coloring books. One had 23 pictures and the other had 32. After one week she had already colored 44 of the pictures. How many pictures does she still have to color?
R:
Rachel originally had 23 + 32 = 55 pictures to color.
After one week, she had colored 44 pictures.
Therefore, she still has 55 - 44 = 11 pictures left to color.

Q: Ned had to wash 9 short sleeve shirts and 21 long sleeve shirts before school. If he had only washed 29 of them by the time school started, how many did he not wash?
R:
Ned washed 9 + 21 = <<9+21=30>>30 shirts in total.
He did not wash 30 - 29 = <<30-29=1>>1 shirt. Answer: \boxed{1}.

Q: Oliver had to wash 39 short sleeve shirts and 47 long sleeve shirts before school. If he had only washed 20 of them by the time school started, how many did he not wash?
R:
Oliver washed a total of 39 + 47 = 86 shirts.
He did not wash 86 - 20 = 66 shirts.

Q: For the school bake sale Wendy made pastries. She baked 4 cupcakes and 29 cookies. After the sale she had 24 to take back home. How many pastries did she sell?
R:
Wendy made a total of 4 + 29 = 33 pastries.
She took 24 pastries back home, so she must have sold 33 - 24 = 9 pastries.

Q: While on vacation, Debby took 24 pictures at the zoo and 12 at the museum. If she later deleted 14 of the pictures, how many pictures from her vacation did she still have?
R:
Debby had a total of 24 + 12 = <<24+12=36>>36 pictures.
After deleting 14 pictures, she had 36 - 14 = <<36-14=22>>22 pictures left. Answer: \boxed{22}.

Q: Katie picked 3 tulips and 9 roses to make flower bouquets. If she only used 10 of the flowers though, how many extra flowers did Katie pick?
R:
Katie picked a total of 3 + 9 = <<3+9=12>>12 flowers.
She had 12 - 10 = <<12-10=2>>2 extra flowers. Answer: \boxed{2}.

Q: Faye had 46 math problems and 9 science problems for homework. If she finished 40 of the problems at school, how many problems did she have to do for homework?
R:
Faye had a total of 46 + 9 = <<46+9=55>>55 problems for homework.
After finishing 40 problems at school, she had 55 - 40 = <<55-40=15>>15 problems left to do for homework. Answer: \boxed{15}.

Q: Amy had 4 music files and 21 video files on her flash drive. If she deleted 23 of the files, how many files were still on her flash drive?
R:
Amy had a total of 4 + 21 = <<4+21=25>>25 files on her flash drive.
After deleting 23 files, she was left with 25 - 23 = <<25-23=2>>2 files on her flash drive. Answer: \boxed{2}.

Q: Ned was trying to expand his game collection. He bought 11 games from a friend and bought 22 more at a garage sale. If 19 of the games didn't work, how many good games did he end up with?
R:
Ned started with 11 games from his friend and added 22 more at the garage sale, for a total of 11 + 22 = 33 games.
If 19 of the games didn't work, then he was left with 33 - 19 = 14 good games. Answer: \boxed{14}.

Q: Chloe was playing a trivia game. In the first round she scored 40 points and in the second round she scored 50 points. In the last round she lost 4 points. How many points did she have at the end of the game?
R:
Chloe had 86 points at the end of the game. 

To find out, you simply add up her scores from the first two rounds: 

40 + 50 = 90 

Then you subtract the 4 points she lost in the last round: 

90 - 4 = 86

Q: At the arcade, Tom won 32 tickets playing 'whack a mole' and 25 tickets playing 'skee ball'. If he spent 7 of his tickets on a hat, how many tickets does Tom have left?
R:
Tom won a total of 32 + 25 = <<32+25=57>>57 tickets.
After buying the hat, he has 57 - 7 = <<57-7=50>>50 tickets left. Answer: \boxed{50}.

Q: Bianca and her mom were picking carrots from their garden. Bianca picked 26 and her mother picked 15. If only 16 of the carrots were good, how many bad carrots did they have?
R:
They picked a total of 26 + 15 = 41 carrots.
If only 16 were good, then they had 41 - 16 = 25 bad carrots.

Q: For the school bake sale Katie made pastries. She baked 7 cupcakes and 5 cookies. After the sale she had 8 to take back home. How many pastries did she sell?
R:
Katie sold a total of 4 pastries. 

To see why, you can use subtraction. 

Start with the total number of pastries Katie had before the sale: 

7 cupcakes + 5 cookies = 12 pastries 

Then subtract the number of pastries she had left after the sale: 

12 pastries - 8 pastries = 4 pastries 

So Katie sold 4 pastries at the bake sale.

Q: Zoe bought two coloring books. One had 44 pictures and the other had 44. After one week she had already colored 20 of the pictures. How many pictures does she still have to color?
R:
Zoe has a total of 44 + 44 = <<44+44=88>>88 pictures.
After one week, she colored 20 pictures, so she still has 88 - 20 = <<88-20=68>>68 pictures to color. Answer: \boxed{68}.

Q: John was trying to expand his game collection. He bought 21 games from a friend and bought 8 more at a garage sale. If 23 of the games didn't work, how many good games did he end up with?
R:
John started with 21 games from his friend and bought 8 more, for a total of 21 + 8 = <<21+8=29>>29 games.
If 23 of the games didn't work, then he was left with 29 - 23 = <<29-23=6>>6 good games. Answer: \boxed{6}.

Q: Henry had 11 dollars. For his birthday he got 18 more dollars but spent 10 on a new game. How much money does he have now?
R:
Henry now has 19 dollars. 

To get this answer, you can add the 18 dollars he received for his birthday to the 11 dollars he already had: 

11 + 18 = 29 

Then, you can subtract the 10 dollars he spent on the new game: 

29 - 10 = 19 

Therefore, Henry now has 19 dollars.

Q: While on vacation, Gwen took 41 pictures at the zoo and 29 at the museum. If she later deleted 15 of the pictures, how many pictures from her vacation did she still have?
R:
Gwen took a total of 41 + 29 = <<41+29=70>>70 pictures on her vacation.
After deleting 15 pictures, she had 70 - 15 = <<70-15=55>>55 pictures left. Answer: \boxed{55}.

Q: Sam had to wash 40 short sleeve shirts and 23 long sleeve shirts before school. If he had only washed 29 of them by the time school started, how many did he not wash?
R:
Sam washed a total of 40 + 23 = 63 shirts.
He did not wash 63 - 29 = 34 shirts. Answer: \boxed{34}.

Q: A pet store had 12 siamese cats and 20 house cats. During a sale they sold 20 cats. How many cats do they have left?
R: The pet store originally had 32 cats (12 siamese + 20 house). After selling 20 cats, they have 12 cats left.

Q: Faye and her mom were picking carrots from their garden. Faye picked 23 and her mother picked 5. If only 12 of the carrots were good, how many bad carrots did they have?
R:
They picked a total of 23 + 5 = <<23+5=28>>28 carrots.
So, they had 28 - 12 = <<28-12=16>>16 bad carrots. Answer: \boxed{16}.

Q: The school cafeteria ordered 43 red apples and 32 green apples for students lunches. But, if only 2 students wanted fruit, how many extra did the cafeteria end up with?
R:
The cafeteria ordered a total of 43 + 32 = 75 apples.
If only 2 students wanted fruit, they would need a total of 2 x 2 = <<2*2=4>>4 apples.
Therefore, the cafeteria ended up with 75 - 4 = <<75-4=71>>71 extra apples. Answer: \boxed{71}.
